text: 1.) What makes internal waves unique compared to other large ocean waves?

options.text: They move underwater and are nearly impossible to see without special equipment.
They are the largest waves in terms of height.
They only occur in specific regions like the Luzon Strait.
They are involved in ocean mixing but do not transfer heat.

text: 2.) Why is understanding internal waves crucial for global climate modeling, according to Tom Peacock?

options.text: Internal waves are responsible for the formation of islands in the ocean.
Internal waves are a significant factor in driving ocean circulations and heat transfer.
Internal waves are essential for predicting earthquakes and tsunamis.
Internal waves are indicators of changing weather patterns.

text: 3.) How did scientists study the formation of internal waves in the Luzon Strait?

options.text: They used satellite imagery to track wave movements.
They conducted experiments in a rotating facility called the Coriolis Platform.
They observed wave patterns from a research vessel in the Luzon Strait.
They created computer simulations to model internal wave behavior.

text: 4.) What will be the potential impact of incorporating information about internal waves into global climate models?

options.text: The models will become less accurate in predicting ocean currents.
The models will be able to simulate weather patterns but not ocean movements.
The models will become more accurate in predicting ocean circulations and heat transfer.
The models will focus primarily on atmospheric changes, neglecting oceanic influences.
